summary: Henry P. Lopez was a CIA asset who worked for the Mexico City Station from 1961 to 1966. Documents detail his activities, expenses, and cover arrangements with the CIA, including the use of proprietary companies and potential operational deployments in Spain. He was also associated with Edward G. Tichborn in some capacity, with documents referencing both individuals together in operational contexts and contract-related matters. Later, he worked as a legal consultant for WUSALINE in New York City. In 1978, the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) requested CIA assistance to interview Lopez in Mexico, indicating his potential relevance to the JFK assassination investigation.
significance: Henry P. Lopez's significance in the JFK context stems from the HSCA's interest in interviewing him in 1978. The documents suggest he had ties to CIA operations in Mexico during the early 1960s, a period relevant to the JFK assassination. The specific reasons for the HSCA's interest are not detailed in these documents, but his association with the CIA and presence in Mexico at the time make him a person of interest to the investigation.
